When I first saw this movie, I thought it was just okay‚Äîbut after watching it a few more times, I‚Äôve really grown to love it. Honestly, if this had been released during Phase 3, I think it would‚Äôve hit even harder. What I really appreciated was how it gave us a deeper connection to Natasha. We finally got to see where she came from, the horrors of the Red Room, and how women were trained‚Äîand tortured‚Äîto become assassins. It added so much depth to her character. I also loved how the movie showed that Natasha had a real family beyond the Avengers. That dynamic made her story more meaningful. In fact, if her family had been more involved or even present after her death in Endgame, I think it would‚Äôve made that moment even more emotional‚Äîbut that‚Äôs just my take. Overall, this is a solid film that gave Black Widow the spotlight she deserved.

Now in the Marvel timeline, this film takes place after *Captain America: Civil War" but "Black Widow" really stands on its on. You do not have to have seen the other Marvel film to enjoy this Awesome origin story of Natasha Romanoff, a Russian spy turned Avenger. It Is 1995, Russian spies Alexei Shostakov and Melina Vostokoff go in deep undercover in Ohio USA. Posed as a family with with two young daughters, Natasha and Yelena, (ages 11 & 6} they steal secret SHIELD intel and return to Russia. But the young girls are taken by General Dreykov and sent to the infamous Red Room and trained to be assassins. "My girls are toughest girls in the world" - Alexei Now twenty years later, the very intel they stole is being used to control "Black Widow" assassins all over the world...including Yelena. Now to stop Dreykov and destroy the Red Room the family must reunite and fight together. But were they ever a real family? "It was real for me" - Yelena "I'm sorry. We had our orders and we played our roles" - Melina Black Widow is my favorite of all the Superhero films.... and it is so much more. This is a great well written story about a unlikely family but with lots of action, mystery, spy and hero stuff, and family feuds and reunions. I saw Black Widow on the big screen when it came out and watching again, I really forgot how good is, Way beyond my expectations..... And a Awesome cast! Some of my favorite actors. Scarlett Johansson, Florence Pugh, David Harbour, Rachel Weisz, Olga Kurylenko, William Hurt, Ray Winstone "Family, back together again." -Alexei

What if I told you I loved this movie despite my hard rating? Well you'd be surprised that the reason I adore this movie is not the reason I should like this movie. Black Widow struggles on its main character, its main antagonist, its visuals, and its story. Everything else is welcomed with open arms. Simply, this movie is awesome not because of Black Widow. The worst part of the movie is the very character it is trying to represent. There are not enough reasons to like Black Widow except that she is played by Scarlett Johansson. The movie gives you enough reasons why we should not like her. She killed a little girl, she abandoned her sister, she killed even more people, etc. I believe the film is trying to get us to show empathy for her. What it did was leave its audience feeling guilty for loving a character for a long period of time.

Taking place after the events of ‚ÄòCaptain America: Civil War‚Äô and before ‚ÄòAvengers: Infinity War‚Äô Natasha Romanoff is on the run after breaking the Sokovia Accords with Steve Rogers escaping custody After 12 years Marvel Studios and director Katie Shortland give Black Widow her own solo adventure at last with her tracing her roots training with the Black Widow program She also comes back Notwithstanding all the drama behind the scenes and in courtrooms, Marvel's Black Widow" is an apt standalone feature for the badass mercenary turned Avenger, diving deep into her back story. While there was plain knowledge that Natasha Romanoff was a defected spy and assassin from Russia, Cate Shortland's film goes right back to her childhood and a fleeting view of events on her journey and affiliation with America. An older child in a family of Russian spies embedded in Ohio, Natasha along with her kid sister Yelena and parents are forced to flee the country when her father, Alexei (David Harbour) is busted after completing a major espionage mission. Natasha is reluctant and fears the return to her country of origin, possibly for things she has seen and experienced, while Alexei and her mother, Melina (Rachel Weisz) are bound by their loyalty to a General Dreykov (Ray Winstone). We then cut forward to a point of time, post the events of "Civil War", with Natasha already an Avenger and on the run for being an outlaw by affiliation with Captain America and the squad that backed him. Yelena (Florence Pugh) is now a brainwashed Black Widow assassin working for Dreykov and his "Red Room", but during a mission to assassinate a rebel is freed from her mind-controlling chemical/drug. Yelena seeks out help from her sister and the rest of her family who have been split and separated over the years, to find Dreykov. And it is indeed a fun reunion. The film is evidently action packed and the action is good, supported by adequate and slick CGI. Scarlett Johansson leads with a punch and a kick-some performance in what might be potentially her last swing as the "Widow". Florence Pugh is an enterprising entry as the younger "Widow"; a rising actress, the film makes way for more of her in the Avengers universe. David Harbour is hilarious in his bits, and Rachel Weisz plays an adequate part in the dysfunctional and bantering but fun family. And there are a couple of interesting cameos from Olga Kurylenko and O. T. Fagbenle (of "The Handmaid's Tale" fame) It isn't something exceptional ‚Äì but it's tightly held together with a good cast and it's definitely better than some of the recent Marvel content that's been out there. Mostly powered by ScarJo and the represented retribution of women breaking out of manipulative strings, #MeToo or otherwise.

"Black Widow" (2021) is a thrilling and well-crafted addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. The plot provides a compelling origin story for the titular character, exploring her past and the events that shaped her into the assassin we know and love. The acting is strong, particularly from lead Scarlett Johansson, who brings nuance and depth to her performance. The supporting cast is also excellent, adding layers to the film's complex world and story. The cinematography is visually stunning, capturing the high-stakes action and espionage with a sleek and stylish flair. The direction is confident and effective, keeping the pacing tight and the tension high. The film's score is pulse-pounding and perfectly complements the on-screen action. However, the film can be criticized for its somewhat formulaic plot and predictable twists. Additionally, the film's villain is underdeveloped and fails to provide a truly compelling threat to the main characters. Overall, "Black Widow" is a thrilling and well-crafted film that provides a satisfying origin story for the titular character. While it may not reach the heights of some of the best films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it is still a solid entry that fans of the franchise will enjoy.

Cate Shortland's long-awaited addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe has finally made its theatrical debut. The film mixes established characters and explosive action in a globe-trotting adventure. Johansson makes her final appearance as the titular hero in a story that delves into past and future events in the elaborate universe. Fresh off the events of 'Captain America: Civil War', Natasha Romanoff (Scarlett Johansson), now a political fugitive, must go into hiding and begin anew after violating the Sokovia Accords. But when her past catches up with her, Natasha must dive back into a dangerous conspiracy, confront the red in her ledger, and outrun an unstoppable force. Cate Shortland makes her MCU debut alongside a star-studded cast that includes Rachel Weisz, Florence Pugh, David Harbour, OT Fagbenle and Ray Winstone. Shortland manages to bring these exciting new characters together in a way that explains who these characters are while keeping the explosive action moving. Johansson once again slips into the role of the Russian spy with ease. She delivers a brilliant performance, making her eighth appearance as the trained assassin the perfect way to end Natasha's story within the MCU. Florence Pugh's Marvel debut allows the talented actress to show off her vast range, bringing the character of Yelena Belova (fellow Black Widow assassin) to the screen. Pugh's performance is comedic and emotional, and her sister-like bond with Natasha is the perfect way to mix some much-needed comedy into the film's dark subject matter. The film's post-credits scene implies that Marvel intends to bring Yelena into the Disney+ series 'Hawkeye', which should arrive Fall of this year. So fans of the blonde assassin shouldn't have to wait long before seeing her back in the MCU. Like every other Marvel production, 'Black Widow' does a splendid job referencing MCU past and future, providing context for previous references. But the film also gives viewers a much-needed insight into Natasha's past life. Despite Marvel's impressive track record in the visual effects department, 'Black Widow' doesn't appear to be up to par with the numerous other MCU projects that came before it. Natalie Abizadeh brings her talent to the screen, providing each character with attractive yet practical hairstyles that range from intricate braids to simplistic ponytails. Even though 'Black Widow' is a Marvel production and comes from a studio most notably known for their big-budget, explosive blockbusters, it still manages to deal with incredibly deep themes such as family, free will and human nature. Shortland features shots of fireflies at both the start and end of the film; these insects resonate with themes such as hope and guidance. But more importantly, fireflies relate to the importance of our internal character, which in Natasha's case is something that the character struggles to deal with. If you're new to watching Marvel's vast, interconnected universe, then 'Black Widow' might not be the best place to start for numerous reasons. Not just because the majority of viewers will already know the events of the 2019 film 'Avengers: Endgame', but because there's a plethora of minor details and references that will fly straight over your head. The stunt choreography displayed over the 134 minutes is a somewhat fresh take on what viewers have previously seen, with no vibranium shields or telekinetic powers. All these characters have to rely on is mundane weapons and their surroundings (e.g. furniture/ home decor), as seen in the Budapest apartment fight scene in which Natasha and Yelena attempt to strangle each other with a curtain. The fact these characters don't have hi-tech weaponry gives it a slight sense of realism and adds another layer of tension. But viewers are moved to the edge of their seats wondering who will win. Overall, 'Black Widow' is a film that is a balanced mix of hilarious comedy, emotional drama and explosive action, led by a stellar cast that each provides brilliant performances in a film that contributes to the Marvel Cinematic Universe in more ways than one. Cate Shortland gifts viewers a heartfelt goodbye to the titular character in the 24th addition to the forever-growing Marvel universe.

Finally we have a Black Widow solo film & it's finally released!!! Although about 7 years too late unfortunately. Don't get me wrong I'm super pumped we have a BW solo film, I just feel it probably should've been out back in 2014 after Winter Solder. Or at least well before the character had been killed off in the MCU. So of course knowing that, this film really didn't have the weight it probably should've. I mean we already know how Natasha's story is going to turn out. All that aside BW was still a very entertaining and highly enjoyable film! Not the best MCU film, but a solid entry. Albeit a weaker storyline. She's basically on a mission to bring down the "Red Room" and people behind it.  While BW was supposed to expand on Natasha's past we get some of that and we are introduced to her "sister" Yelena Belova portrayed to perfection by Florence Pugh. Yelena was pretty much the stand out for me. I suppose that is a good thing as she's most likely going to be taking up the mantle now. Yelena is a very likable and at times funny character. She's able to go toe to toe with Natasha as well as hold her own in fights. Between Yelena & Natasha you didn't really need the other "family" characters. Their dynamic together was awesome. They felt like true sisters. Melina (the mom) was ok, but barely any excitement or much use for her. Alexei/Red Guardian (the dad) was completely useless. He did not have a single thing to do and very little action. Both of those characters could've been omitted for me. They didn't lean much into the family dynamics as they could've so I felt both of them were just there for the sake of padding the talking scenes as neither had much action or furthered the story.  Speaking of the action, BW fell into WW84s problem in the third act. The third act here was more of a spectacle than WW84, but still very minimal hand to hand fighting. There was a brief scene with Natasha vs the other Widows, Red Guardian vs Taskmaster and Natasha vs Taskmaster. All of which were concluded so fast it made the big finale sequence very underwhelming. Speaking of Taskmaster there is a twist with the character, but still it's used very minimal. There was a pretty decent sequence early on on a bridge with Taskmaster and Natasha which was probably the standout. Other than that the character was very under utilized and subsequently "defeated" too quickly. The first half of the movie had some pretty good excitement and entertaining sequences, but slows down until the sloppy final act. This film had a lot of potential, but while enjoyable, it didn't live up to to that potential unfortunately. The end credit scene is actually really nice and helps set up some future stories. I will definitely check this out again as BW deserves her solo film, but just wish it were slightly better story wise and come along a lot sooner.

Black Widow is Marvel's spy thriller, and despite its issues, the movie is still entertaining. Scarlett Johansen's Black Widow is a fun character, although her character is undercut by the fact that we already know her fate in Avengers: Endgame (this movie was supposed to be made and released before Endgame). Florence Pugh's Yelena steals the show, and the rest of the cast is also well-acted and adds some humor and emotion. And though the action scenes are entertaining, and the emotional moments tug on the heartstrings, Black Widow has some flaws. The stakes are more personal than global, which is fine considering what we know happens to Natasha Romanoff later on. The villain isn't exciting, but this movie is more about the personal redemption and arc of Romanoff than the villain (for better or worse). But the bigger problems lie in the secondary villain and action scenes. Taskmaster had so much potential to be a great villain, and though they had some great action scenes, the charcater was totally undercut by the end of the movie. The action, though fun, was very brutal and doled out vast punishment to the characters. If these were superpowered heroes, that would be fine, but both Nat and Yelena are regular humans that should not survive the damage they take in this movie. The final action scene is fun, but for such a grounded movie, feels very out-of-place. Overall, Black Widow suffers the most from such a delayed release, but the majority of it is fun enough to be worth a watch.

Black Widow can be summed up in one sentence: Marvel x James Bond / Mission Impossible. This movie relied more on action set pieces and big explosions to make up for the adherent lack of superpowers in this movie, which I really dug. Watching Black Widow, Yelena Belova, Red Guardian and Taskmaster all fight hand to hand, skilled combat was really awesome and a refreshing break from superpowers that was rather needed, and I would say I preferred this to the standard superpower fight scenes. The newly introduced characters of Red Guardian and Yelena Belova created many more exciting opportunities for future movies and the potential replacement Black Widow in Yelena Belova. However, I would have to say that they ruined Taskmaster, as they made her totally different from the comics, which although that didn't bother me turning her into a superhero really ruined any chance of Taskmaster as a future villain and the remaining part needed for the Thunderbolts. General Ross had a unique but confusing appearance in which he was included but generally forgotten about with a time skip stopping us from seeing why he was there, but as long as it's justified in a later film I'm good with it. The main villain was Dreykov, a rather forgettable villain that was rather basic although needed to set up the next movies in phase 4 and the progression of Yelena Belova for future movies. The end credits scene hints at a future movie where we will see Yelena Belova vs Ronin which I am super hyped to see and definitely can't wait to see. Overall, Black Widow set up a great amount of new movies and was a really good start to Phase 4 of Marvel movies.

Florence Pugh outshines all of her cast mates in "Black Widow", including leading lady Scarlett Johansson who also delivers a passionate performance. Unfortunately, this duo wasn't a good enough distraction from the film's wonky CGI, weak antagonists, and perplexing action sequences.

I started to lose interest in the MCU after Acengers:Endgame. I found it too portentous, way too long and narratively lazy. The combined forces of that and COVID kept me away. Then Disney+ arrive in my lounge, I want something new but not taxing on a bad Long Covid day. This was just the ticket. It's the love child of Marvel and Mission:Impossible, complete with terrific stunts and action set pieces. The central villain's plot may seem hard to pin down, but Johansson is good and it's lovely to see the always excellent Florence Pugh given a key role in a film like this. There's a pleasing lack of the meaningless cityscape destruction that so often features in superhero films, and Marvel's trademark style of wit fits well in the action spy context. Fans of the tv show Alias like me may spot some of its influence also, and it seemed to me that there's more than sniff of a feminist take about this that works pleasingly (though of course women should critique that). Yes it's still quite generic (and, of course, overlong ‚Ä¶ but not Endgame overlong at least), but the mix of genres definitely gives it a different feel throughout, to the extent that even Ray Winstone's absurd attempt at an accent doesn't jar too much. Terrific entertainment just when I needed it, I'm freshly motivated to try catching up with the rest of the MCU films I've missed.

This is an entertaining ride. There are numerous scenes that are absolutely ridiculous, even for a superhero film. take 30 punches and get up? Ok I guess you are juiced up or super trained or something. I'd expected this from Thor Ragnarok, but Black Widow? That said, I was totally entertained. The characters are multifaceted, (some of them) and often entertaining as well as looking or being badass. There is the right amount of comedy sprinkled in. The fight scenes don't tend to last TOO long or get dull. There is a LOT of human damage that gets hand waived and I gets the Sykovia Accords make sense, hmm? Watching this in order, right after Civil War, was great. There are quite a number of tie-ins that serve to link this story to those before and after it. I appreciated those details. In the end I loved some of the new characters (Pugh was great!) and had a good time - through three 45min viewing sessions. Streaming has spoiled me and these MCU flicks can be long.

Whilst I am glad the MCU has finally given its first female superhero her own solo film, Natasha Romanoff does not feel like the main character in her own story. The film does a nice job delving into Natasha as a character, but only provides glimpses of her background - one that acts as social commentary for child trafficking, an aspect of the film brought up during the intro sequence but is otherwise largely ignored for the rest of the film. One of the bigger problems that seem consistent across all Marvel Studios productions, is how they add humor inappropriately during points of the film where it tries to deal with serious topics. In Black Widow, a saving grace is that the comedy was fairly enjoyable. Black Widow also suffers from Marvel Studios' villain problem, where its primary antagonists are barely characters and more so plot points that exist for a conflict to occur. We learn very little about Natasha's rivals and they ultimately felt like unnecessary and uninteresting additions to the MCU. The best aspect of the film to me was the cast. Scarlett Johansson reprises her role as Natasha Romanoff and does an excellent job in the role as usual. Joining her are Florence Pugh, Rachel Weisz, and David Harbour who make up the most enjoyable and heartfelt moments in the film.

Too little and too late, that's the simple single-sentence review for Black Widow which finally released after four post-production delays. Of course, those delays are not the reason why this film came about too late, that was always going to be an issue. Black Widow takes place between the 2016 Captain America: Civil War and the 2018 Avengers: Infinity War with Natasha Romanoff (Scarlet Johansson) being a fugitive on the run following the Avengers breaking up over disagreements regarding government surveillance. This middle-of-the-road placement of the film doesn't affect the main narrative much as it's isolated to characters unique to this film rather than the more crossover-heavy films the MCU have put out lately, but at the same time it can't be ignored that the film feels like it should have been released in 2017 rather than after the 2019 Avengers: Endgame where Natasha ultimately was killed off. Her fate in Endgame being sealed does hurt some of the tension in the film since even if you wouldn't expect a Black Widow film to kill her off, the fact that it literally can't kill her off alters your perspective quite a bit. It's just unfortunate and a testament to how Disney's reluctance to make this film for the longest time has left scars in the script that can't heal. The story involves Natasha reuniting with her foster-sister, Yelena (Florence Pugh), from before her indoctrination into The Red Room, the global network of assassins that take little girls and turn them into programmed killers. Natasha and Yelena set out to take down The Red Room. It's fairly straight forward and you most likely figured out the few twists in the story from just watching the trailer. It's clear that the film wants to evoke more of a James Bond vibe than a typical superhero film, from the opening title sequences set to an awkward slowed down cover of Smells Like Teen Spirit to the more visceral and violent action scenes feeling right out of the Daniel Craig Bond films that take up the first half of the film. It's a breath of fresh air that unfortunately is lost in the final act when it becomes a more standard superhero film despite all this. The performances in the film works quite well with Johansson looking far more comfortable as Natasha in this film than in any of the seven films she was in before this. Pugh as Yelena is the stand-out star and the hints that she'll take up the Black Widow mantle in future MCU media is something I welcome. Black Widow is not a terrible film, but it's also not a decent film. It's a dull if inoffensive action adventure that awkwardly tries to slot itself in between other films to not have to deal with the fact that they waited so long to make this film that the character had both been killed off in-universe and lost most of her popularity from nearly a decade ago. It's certainly not worth going back to theaters or paying a Disney+ premium price for, that's for sure.

I have absolutely no idea why this movie was released in 2021 or why it was the opening act for the fourth phase of the MCU. This movie would have been immensely more interesting had it been released following Civil War which is when the story takes place. The fact of the matter is that it's a story that didn't need to be told for a character whose storyline is finished in the present of the MCU. While I believe you can tell a story about a character who is no longer alive, you have to make the story matter. This story absolutely didn't matter. It's serves as a quasi-origin story at the beginning with a side story about Natasha dealing with her life as an assassin with no family. There are some touching moments, and the characters have decent chemistry together, but the movie felt so unnecessary. It was clearly made to be a big-budget 2 hour lead in to the Hawkeye show. This seems to be the beginning of a dark period for the MCU. Many of its heavy hitters have tied a bow on their storylines which means Marvel will try to squeeze out as many stories as they can from any other superhero still remaining. What's unfortunate is that Far From Home made me feel like the MCU could continue even without Iron Man and Captain America. However, if the future MCU movies continue to maintain the quality of Black Widow, I'll probably just stick with the movies of established heroes that are remaining from the Infinity Saga.

Black Widow, directed by Cate Shortland. The main character is Natasha Romanoff, played by Scarlett Johansson. The story is about a young girl who is part of an experience to put young girls in combat. This experience destroys her life. One day she finds her little sister who was also in this experience. The two sisters go in pursuit of the red room where the experience happened, to kill the person responsible for the experience. They are then accompanied by their parents who actually helped in the experience, particularly the mom. The special effects are inventive, the photography is incredible So I find this movie realistic and impressive. I recommend to go and see it if you like action movies.

Black Widow was produced by Cate ShortLand in 2021. Natasha, the main character is played by Scarlett Johansson. It is an action movie that is about Natasha and her sister, Yolona, who were recruited by Russian government to become "black widow" and fight the American government. Few years later, Natasha side with American and she became an Avengers. Yolana escape from black widow organisation and they fight together Russian government to free every black widow. The plot is basic to action movie, but the ending is poignant. Special effects are superb, especially with pan shot and long shot. The acting is stunning, the casting is amazing. The script is very interesting, characters are dive few years later after the Cold War, but we could feel tension between USA and Russia. This movie is outstanding, acting is perfect and, despite a poor plot, and I love Cold war references. I recommend this film everyone love historic and action movie.

Rescue scene at Russian prison was also awesome. Who expected an avalanche?! Nice touch. Other facts: Johansson sued Disney studios for releasing the movie digitally on Disney Plus too soon after movie hit the theaters. Johansson felt it a breach of contract. Johansson and Disney settled for an unnamed amount. Johansson was seeking 50 million in damages. The suit alleged that Johansson lost out on tens of millions of dollars in box office bonuses.
